awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Multi-Scale Experimental Mechanics Education Module
awd_abstract_narration:
This project focuses on combining solid mechanics experimentation and material visualization to enhance undergraduate solid mechanics education and assist students to develop appropriate mental models of abstract engineering concepts to enhance learning.  This effort employs multiple length scale material characterization and visualization for solid mechanics education, web-based education modules, and experiential learning.  A broad impact of this research is a contribution to the education of future professional engineers in fundamental solid mechanics and increase in the critical number of individuals who are capable of translating STEM advances into engineering innovations.

This research project is pilot testing the effectiveness of mechanics education by establishing the relation of material structure and solid mechanics, which can assist students in understanding complex and abstract concepts in engineering.  To understand whether the proposed approach can improve student learning and retention of course materials covered, Primary Trait Analysis, Student Assessment of Learning Gains Surveys, and individual student interviews are being used to analyze and compare students' learning outcomes with conventional methods.  Changes in Student Mental Model Representation are being analyzed through a language-oriented methodology for text and graphical representations of open problems.  Pre- and post-experiments are being used to compare and track changes in students' mental representation. The measures are also being used to compare control and treatment groups.  Students' perceptual and motivational characteristics are being assessed using a multi-scale questionnaire instrument previously designed and validated by project personnel.

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
This collaborative IUSE project created significant educational technology innovations and successfully implemented the developed education and training modules to improve undergraduate solid mechanics education in both in-person and remote learning environments. The project first obtained mechanical testing and image database for a broad range of engineering materials, including polymers, composites, nanocomposites, and metals. A multi-scale education module was then created using the collected mechanical testing data and images. A unique feature of the education module was to establish the bridges of materials performance and properties across three length scales, including micro, meso, and macro. This approach assisted engineering students in developing concept maps connecting fundamental concepts and principles across multiple disciplines. The developed education module has been released online to promote implementation at multiple universities. Due to the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic, virtual reality environments were created to conduct multi-scale mechanical testing at both micro and macro length scales, allowing students and educators to enable remote and virtual mechanical testing and imaging in the created education module. To evaluate the effectiveness of the developed education module, significant efforts were spent to develop evaluation exams that could best represent students’ understanding of fundamental concepts related to solid mechanics, materials, and manufacturing. The developed education module was freely disseminated to students at several universities. The results of all modules have been presented and published in ASEE conferences and journal articles. Six graduate students and seven undergraduate students worked on this project during the project period. Additionally, our collaboration with Tuskegee University also demonstrated the effectiveness of the developed multiscale education module for minority students.

Modules created in this project included significant extensions to other disciplines, including advanced materials, additive manufacturing, materials characterization, and virtual reality-enhanced learning. The developed education module has been improved, considering the students’ learning outcomes and feedback, as well as the academic background of different student groups.

The collaborative nature of the project helped establish a national and international community of users. In addition to mechanical testing and characterization-based education modules and products, this project produced multidisciplinary engineering education approaches and products at the University of Oklahoma and Tuskegee University.


Last Modified: 06/14/2023
Modified by: Yingtao Liu
